I find that for intraday forex  trend  trading most important relevant (Guide)trend direction is ON 15 minute, 1h and 4h charts only-- For intraday trading weekly & monthly trends do not matter much(too far removed from intraday field of activity) & can be ignored. For simplicity sake if 15 minute ,1h & 4h trends are in the same direction, you have a trade  set up in the same direction (one could fine tune entry 0n 5 minute charts). In general if daily candle  be in the same direction for any trade it is better but not A must.--Sir, what do you  have to say?

How did he calculate that Bet A always beats Bet B? Wasnt that wrong?

Moreover, poisson distribution can be applied only if the mean rate of events per unit of time is constant. However, in case of sovereign bond default, the mean default rate per unit of time can never be  practically constant.

The interest rate differential  being the positive drift in the currency exchange rate is well explained but  the probability of sovereign default (h) and the probable time of default can be far better explained by macro economic factors  rather than statistical modelling through poisson distribution. As sovereign  default is an outlier event, so  macro economics analysis is must for predicting the same.

The "Poisson distribution" he mentioned through the whole lecture is actually the exponential distribution.

I think he got mistaken between EUR/USD and USD/EUR. In his example he took USD/EUR = 1.25 for the first scenario meaning the 100$ are worth 125€. He did the opposite in his slides, stating that the 100€ were worth 125$.   So for scenario 1, the best bet is actually bet B, because in bet A you lose 100$=125€ so you lose  25€ more than bet B. For scenario 2, the best bet il still bet B, because now 100$=75€ so you win 25€ less in bet A than bet B.  He just mistook USD/EUR for EUR/USD.

*Poisson process, which the exp. dist. can follow
Carmi Shen What do you mean?
Josh Miller What do you mean?

If the number of occurrences in a fixed time period follows Poisson distribution, then the time intervals between two occurrences follows exponential distribution. And vice versa. So in this Poisson process, the time between Tau’s (in this case, from beginning to the first occurrences. The beginning can be seen as the last occurrence before we start counting) follow exponential distribution. FYI, the time between the beginning to the kth occurrences follow Gamma distribution.
